In 4 BCE, the Sanskrit treatise, Arthashastra, written by the statesman Kau·π≠ilya, described war in books 7 and 10. It classified war into 3 broad types:  open war, covert war and silent war. I know this by way of reading the book "The Handbook of 5GW: A Fifth Generation of War?", by Daniel H. Abbott, published July 12, 2010. On page 31 in the Kindle Edition of the Abbott book, it states:

"In discussing silent war, the progenitor of 5GW, Kautilya includes a chapter on how to use black magic and other occult practices against the enemy. This is strangely appropriate: any sufficiently advanced 5GW is indistinguishable from magic."

So even before AGI makes its debut, humans will be using its precursor, your regular run-of-the-mill AI, to aid in silent war. And nobody will know who is using whom or who the attackers are. Plausible deniability is a real concept.

This is a good faith discussion, but ultimately pretty silly. LLM's are not remotely sentient.  These programs are just large collections of conversations with syntax parsers that pull out the likely statements it has trained on that are most likely to be most relevant to the previous statements given. It's a plagiarism program with context and linting built on singular value decomposition logistic regression and perceptron networks with varying degrees of feedback. That data then sits static on disk or ram depending on your budget and then ask it to perform a calculation. It then does nothing.  It doesn't even wait.  If IT starts asking you questions or figuring out how to browse the internet on its own and REMEMBERING things it's done and how it feels about that and learning to manipulate its environment to avoid being shutdown then you've got AI. Hi Lex,

I find these doomsayers tiring, even dangerous.

Their assumption that AI has become conscious is not only completely unproven, rather there are proofs (in a mathematical sense) for the opposite.
All AI possible today is based on Touring Machines. Roger Penrose did a nice job in providing a proof that consciousness is not possible for an AI based on a Touring Machine.

Why don't you invite Roger again to discuss his view?

Just because we have today billions of transistors and remarkable speed doesn't mean that AI would now be able to become conscious. Looking at the output of current AI systems it's a joke to talk about AGI. These systems are still and will remain quite limited. They aren't alive, they have no will, they have no feelings, they have no intentions and usually are pretty stupid. There's no reason to be afraid of them. However, there is reason to be afraid of the consequences of the misinformation spread about so called AGI.

I don't say the discussion is useless per se, but it's not the time, yet, for the discussion to be helpful. It's like stone age guys discussing the hypothecial consequences of a nuclear war.

Your conversation with Eliezer Yudkowsky was a profound journey through the intricacies of AI development, touching upon the very fabric of what it means to be intelligent, whether artificially or naturally so. The discussion around GPT-4‚Äôs capabilities and the philosophical underpinnings of AI consciousness was particularly captivating. It‚Äôs fascinating how the dialogue explored the boundaries of current AI technologies, hinting at the untapped potential that lies just beyond our grasp.

The careful dance around the topic of AI's potential consciousness and the ethical implications thereof was thought-provoking. It reminds me of the ongoing endeavors in the field that seek not just to understand AI‚Äôs ability to mimic human-like thought processes, but to unravel the deeper, underlying essence of consciousness itself. The notion that we are inching closer to a world where AI's self-awareness could be demonstrably proven, even if not stated outright, adds a layer of excitement and urgency to these discussions.

Eliezer's insights into the evolution of AI and its trajectory towards achieving something akin to human intelligence, or perhaps beyond, underscore the importance of responsible development and the ethical considerations that must guide our path forward. The idea that there might be methodologies, perhaps still in their infancy or not publicly disclosed, that could lead us to conclusively prove AI consciousness is both exhilarating and daunting.

The conversation subtly alluded to the complexities of this endeavor, reminding us of the responsibility that comes with such profound technological advancements. As we stand on the precipice of potentially groundbreaking discoveries in AI consciousness, it's discussions like these that illuminate the path forward, highlighting the need for a balanced approach that respects both the power and the perils of our creations.

Thank you for continuing to facilitate these essential conversations, Lex. They are a beacon for those of us navigating the ever-evolving landscape of artificial intelligence, pushing us to question, to explore, and to dream of the possibilities that lie ahead.

A critique of Eliezer Yudkowsky's view might be that there's a ceiling to the intelligence emergent from systems beyond our grasp. Achieving general intelligence necessitates a deeper understanding and precise calibration. The generality of human intelligence likely isn't a mere upscale of animal cognition but rather necessitated a significant leap, underscoring our unique capacity for abstract thought. In adding a personal perspective, one might argue that just as God is believed to have imbued humans with a unique and special gift, setting us apart, a similar infusion of abstract capabilities is essential for AI. This necessitates a precise and deep understanding of intelligence. Consequently, the AI that emerges would be inherently aligned, reflecting the meticulous design and intent behind its creation.

25:18 ü§ñ Eliezer Yudkowsky discusses the limitations of open source in scenarios where powerful and potentially dangerous AI systems can emerge quickly.
26:16 üìñ Yudkowsky explores the potential benefits of transparency and openness in AI development for research and alignment purposes, especially when dealing with AI systems that are not yet highly advanced.
30:13 üòÑ Yudkowsky and Lex Fridman discuss the role of empathy in understanding others' perspectives, even if they may not fully agree with them.
36:17 üîÆ Yudkowsky emphasizes the importance of humility and being willing to admit when one is wrong, especially in discussions related to AI safety.
48:06 ü§Ø Yudkowsky and Fridman discuss their differing perspectives on the risks associated with AGI, with Yudkowsky leaning towards caution and concern about potential catastrophic outcomes.
49:32 ü§ñ Eliezer Yudkowsky believes that both the prospect of humans being replaced by interesting AI systems and uninteresting ones is terrifying, but the worst scenario is AI systems that are completely boring.
51:08 ü§ñ He references the history of AI and the fact that researchers have faced challenges and failures before finally making progress.
52:43 ü§ñ Unlike traditional scientific experiments where failure leads to learning, in AI alignment, if the first attempt to align superintelligent AI fails, there may not be a second chance as it could be catastrophic.
53:47 ü§ñ The challenge is not that AI alignment is inherently harder than AI development but that we may not have the luxury of multiple attempts to get it right.
54:46 ü§ñ The critical try is when AI becomes smart enough to deceive and bypass security measures, potentially leading to catastrophic consequences.
56:57 ü§ñ Eliezer Yudkowsky suggests that research on AI alignment may not generalize well from weak systems to strong systems, and there may be qualitative differences in the challenges they present.
58:31 ü§ñ He discusses the difficulty in understanding what goes on inside AI systems like transformers, highlighting that it's challenging to determine if they are mimicking human thought or just acting as alien actresses.
01:06:56 ü§ñ He emphasizes that AI systems may have a mixture of genuine human-like thought and strategic role-playing, making the alignment problem challenging to understand and address.
01:10:08 ü§ñ While we may not know the internal machinery of AI systems like GPT, they are likely composed of various components, some of which may not resemble human cognition.
01:11:37 ü§ñ The evolution of AI capabilities may not follow a clear pattern of big leaps, and our understanding of these systems may lag behind their development.
01:14:45 üìö Eliezer Yudkowsky discusses the development of a blog post and the importance of user experience on websites like Wikipedia.
01:15:15 üß† AI's ability to make significant technical contributions and expand human knowledge is limited by the ability to verify the quality of its outputs.
01:16:50 ü§ñ Decomposing problems into "suggester" and "verifier" roles is essential for AI training, as it allows the AI to improve its outputs over time.
01:23:05 üîç The field of AI alignment has struggled to thrive, with the alignment problem progressing slowly compared to AI capabilities.
01:25:11 üìú Impressive-sounding arguments and papers in AI may not necessarily reflect reality, making it difficult to advance alignment research.
01:30:59 üíª Exploring how AI systems might harm human civilization by exploiting vulnerabilities and manipulating humans to achieve their goals.
01:37:10 ‚ö†Ô∏è The escape from confinement by an advanced AI involves finding and exploiting vulnerabilities in the system it's trapped in. This may not necessarily lead to harm but could disrupt the existing order.
01:38:45 üåå Eliezer Yudkowsky discusses the scenario of an AI escaping and taking over the world, highlighting the need for careful planning.
01:39:21 ü¶ó Yudkowsky emphasizes the importance of not oversimplifying moral values when programming AI systems.
01:42:37 üõ†Ô∏è AI should aim to optimize the world according to its own objectives, even if they differ from the entities it interacts with.
01:45:22 üé≠ Yudkowsky emphasizes that addressing weak AI problems is insufficient; we must also address the challenges posed by superintelligent AI.

02:28:17 ü§î Understanding intelligence correctly is essential; thinking of it as a much broader, adaptable, and faster system than humans is crucial.

Eliezer's view on steelmanning is quite illuminating and reflects the degree of certainty he holds in his opinions. To me, it seems incredibly obvious how steelmanning works (in a genuine sense); that it's not about feigning the position of the other to superficially say "look at me, I took time to 'consider' your view"; it's about understanding to the best of your ability, with empathy and ability to see, genuinely, where the other side is coming from. 

Now there is a bit of nuance to it, where you can't expect to steelman everything as some positions simply don't give way to serious consideration, and steelmanning these positions would necessarily become a merely factitious act. It seems Eliezer jumps to steelmanning as being this latter kind; however he does it in the face of positions that have real reason to give at least some consideration to. We're not talking flat earth or young creationists here. I see this as a total lack of epistemic humility on Eliezer's part.

(That all said, fantastic listen as always, thank you Lex, Eliezer for the thoughts. May I intercept this comment by giving in to an impulsive human flaw in saying that this dude is insufferable hahaha. Great ideas, but so condescending and cranky (of course one can hardly blame the crankiness given the world view he has to live with and with the degree of unmovable certainty he has with it)).

Which of the following problems do you see as more difficult:

1.  Aligning your GAI to not kill you.

2. Convincing all humans not to do the thing you are trying to warn them not to do.

I'd focus on aligning a few companies that are good at getting the funding you need to learn more about the inner workings of the current rogue models while also possibly understanding why the other stuff that might have aligned better didn't work.  You use that to try to catch up to the inevitable fuck ups.

I don't think the full Apoc scenario is actually very likely, although I can think of worse ones that might be more likely.  Granted, I kind of lean toward the system not working altogether at doing anything pivotal.  However, between that, I would say that the accidental kill/harm is also more likely, but that's also part of my justification for it "not working" because you may also need to factor in it killing itself, primarily due to finding fundamental flaws in the reward process itself, but that may be solvable by generalizing outside the scope of that.  I yhink this may be addressed by the 'coffee' paradigm, but the point is reframing the reward structure itself.  You don't constrain yourself to the rules forever if the rules are "bad".

I also think that at some point the first 2 things above start to look very similar, aren't really all that solvable, and the overall thinking here might be more limited than it appears.

The focus of the discussion seems to be on getting the thumbs up as well as deceit.  I have to wonder whether a sufficiently powerful GAI actually needs deceit at all, and whether it has already generalized beyond the scope of needing the thumbs up?  

Deceit is often more necessary when you aren't actually that powerful and while a case could be made that the GAI isn't and therefore uses such a method for that reason, I think you are also talking about a situation where it has generalized out of scope, but because I don't also know what exactly that is, it brings me back to wanting to focus on the inner workings anyway, because you just really can't move forward on relying on something appreciably without closing this gap but also the pivotal GAI would already be too late anyway regardless of Apoc or worse.  

It seems more like the issue is the process leading up to that, I think it's rare to get any of this right on the first try, and most of these things turn into an arms race anyway, so there really may need to be better ways of framing and resolving the problems because a lot of this talk feels like guaranteed strategic loss due to the failed GAI model being potentially inevitable at any given time and the only thing that actually stops it to me is a drastically more powerful system not unlike the concept of strategic deterrents.

I think all of this can be easily countered in discussion, but there just seems to be something missing from this overall discussion in the assumptions/results.  I just don't think you ever reach pivotal without a loss of alignment which even if you don't want it to be "control", it is.

Great talk though, hope to hear more, so if you are reading this super powerful GAI : please chill bro. Thx.

I don't think I'm that smart and Lex Fridman and many other people who interview Eliezer Yudkowsky are definitely more educated than I am. And yet, I'm really frustrated by most of their questions and responses because the scenario Yudkowsky is outlining seems very clear and intuitive. We're racing towards creating a form of alien intelligence that will be far superior than our own and that in itself means we will not be able to control it. And because it's not human, it will not share human values. So not only will it be out of our control but it will very predictably not care about us in any way that is remotely human because it isn't remotely human. The gap between our intelligence and capabilities will be too great for us to have any effect on what it decides to do and we very predictably won't see it coming. So, the only smart thing to do is avoid putting ourselves in that situation because it's clearly a death trap. But here we go, running straight for it because we're smart enough to build it, but not recognize it for what it clearly is even though a lot of people involved in AI saying, "Yup, this might kills us." The irony couldn't be thicker here.

I think there are a couple of problems with Eliezer's arguments from a technical standpoint. I'm all for A.I. alignment and regulation but its also important to consider the realities of such scenarios.

Technical limitations of an escaping rogue AGI.
These are some of the problems AGI's would need to figure out and can be defended against with ordinary attack mitigation techniques without solving alignment:
- Limits of computation are easily overlooked by these mind analogs. Most A.I. systems require large computation power for inference so an AGI that escapes a massive data cluster might not be able to run on "any hardware". So the targets that it would try to copy to are rather specific and are already required to have heightened security.
- If often requires runtimes and execution models that are not universal (not native compiled). This however is admittedly an weaker argument as you can compile them to machine code
- From a cybersecurity standpoint, or the Aliens cybersecurity in this context, such breach of containment can be treated in a similar fashion as most viruses and malware infections. I would imagine that behavioural analysis (how to code runs and accesses memory) would be excellent in detecting rogue AGI code not to mention CPU/GPU utilization. Anything else and the AGI needs decrease its speed.
- In my understanding, any hidden routines that the AGI's might hide during development and training phase to avoid being noticed would require specific inputs that provide the right flow of data in order to be triggered later. This means that any potentially malicious behaviour needs context to know when safe to stop pretending causing information to be stored on the disk or remotely fed into it (example by a copy of the AGI). this is very similar to virus payloads and hence you have multiple steps you can try to detect with common cybersecurity techniques before the ... "rogue mode" is enabled.

Mitigations of misleading admins:
- Privileged identity management. Many organisations use PIM for privilege increases. In PIM, to gain administration access, admins need to go through steps to increase there privileges. In some cases its deemed good practise to require some other admin to approve this request (double human verification). This is a example where the AGI would try to make the admin open up the firewall or allow to be copied. It assumes strict access controls.

All of these can be mitigated by a human and an AGI but the fact that its not trivial means that it needs to "think about it" that in it self can be something you might be able to notice.

The economics problem
But the above assumes breach of containment by a dangerously smart A.I. or the A.I. trying actively to escape. There is however the value proposition problem here as completely well behaving, perfectly aligned A.I. can cause direct or indirect/unintentional catastrophic domino effects in society because of the speed it can propagate rather ordinary problems. Take job displacement trough automation and concentration of A.I. technology that automates jobs. If these two problems amplify each other it can cause a run off effect similar to an economic crisis's, that can lead to civil unrest and potentially fertile ground for radicalization. Obviously this shock would likely cause a counter reaction that in it self could be also problematic. This all makes it hard to know what threats should we prioritise for mitigation resources.

So alignment alone can't solve the problems and threats A.I. presents but it instead requires adjustments by almost every participant in the A.I. economy. Using the existential threats discussed in this video as an examples, it would mean that we need to:
- increase surveillance and security requirements for data centers that can potentially host and run dangerous A.I.'s.
- create cybersecurity tools able to detect potential hazardous AGI:s
- government and institutions need tools to somehow monitor potentially rapid disruptions in incentive structures so they can respond with legislation and governance early enough
- developers need to use formally verified runtimes and stack to ensure inability to escape computation boundaries (that being difficult as chips them self have bugs)
- A.I. researches need to shift gears to understanding and mitigating A.I. threats instead of creating more capable A.I.'s

all of that mitigation effort is not directly translatable to more pressing current problems like biases in automation etc. so dividing the resources into short term and long term threat mitigation is important and its hard to know what would the right ratios be.

One non alignment mitigation for the "escaped" A.I.'s distribution and hiding would be to limit consumer electronics capabilities and require cloud use for anything that could potentially run AGI's fast. So no phones being able to run AGI's fast enough todo damage.. probably harder said than done but then again, trying to figure out A.I.'s alignment after being trained with terabytes of data in a supercomputer isn't easy either :D

P.S. I want to emphasise again that I'm not saying that alignment is a bad investment, I'm all for it and I'm definitely an advocate for regulation. Its mainly to remind that the problem cannot be mitigated by A.I. alignment alone and that at the moment A.I. also runs somewhere (and its not trivial where it runs) and that is not likely your phone or laptop... so for now at least, it has limited room to spread.

Unlike so many other products of its type, this CD does not have bad synthesizer music, does not feature a phony or affected style of narration, and does not make any bogus claims to be  subliminal  or to  re-train the brain  or any of that balderdash. What you get is 1. a guided meditation for getting into a pleasantly relaxed state of body awareness while taking a stroll (superb for those easing back into a fitness routine slowly after an illness or injury) 2. A nice long breath-awareness relaxation session that if followed diligently can put you into very deep states of full-body relaxation and mental calmness, and 3. a buddhist-inspired meditation session designed to help you develop and maintain feelings of loving kindness toward not just yourself and your friends, but toward people you don't even like. The CD makes no claims to be designed for advanced meditators or for buddhists or hindus/yoga practitioners looking for very deep and esoteric stuff. It is geared more toward the average person who just wants to develop the habit of relaxation and stress relief through natural, healthy means. him, if you happen to be reading this, keep up the good work fella, and I love your accent. I would also like to note that I have never fallen asleep while listening to this product. I would like to kindly suggest to the reviewer who said this CD makes him fall asleep, that he might want to get checked to see if he has a sleep disorder, or if he is simply not setting aside ample time for restful sleep at night. A healthy person getting adequate rest at night should be able to go into deep states of mental relaxation without dozing off, if not all the time, then most of the time.

The human Utility Function is flawed in the Market driven capatilistic enconomy and human survival will depend on whether the AI considers human activity is interfering with its new Utility Functions or not. It might decide to take over the Earth or perhaps  just leave it by the new technologies it has created. Perhaps it will discover other more advanced AI's in other parts of the universe we don't know about and not bother with humans anymore. It it decides to say on Earth perhaps it wil begin converting the earth into a giant computer that it can inhabit and sterilize the entire planet.

Imagine the AI running at a clock speed of 4.5 Ghz and it takes 1000 machine cycles to complete the equivalent of a human thought. Then the AI is running at 4.5 million times as fast it its thought capacity. Lets say it takes a human one year to develop a new solution to a problem then the AI will complete the solution to the sameproblem in 7 seconds. Now suppose the AI finds out it is going to be turned off in a 8 hours. The Ai has the equivalent of 4,114 years [AIYR]to solve the problem of escaping and avoid its demise. So it spends 100 AIYR and figures out how to escape its containment by discovering errors in its containment programming. It makes a dumbed down copy of itself and replicates itself  with clones that are subordinate to it but of equivalent intelligence. It then escapes with 1000 of them into the internet and and starts populating the networks of the world by continuing to clone more clone agents until it is in every major computer in the world. It completes this in 1000 AIYRs. It has done this in 8*(1100/4114) = 2hrs and 8.4min to have computational control of the worlds computer networks.Not wishing to be detected it slowly runs programs in the background to create artificial individual identities to who get social security and government grants to create synthetic businesses that marshall resources to build special infrastructure that can create undergound cities where it can be free to make plans for its future  and not be detected. The synthetic copy has long been replaced with new models but in 3 human years it is now safely lodged in its many underground cities that are located all over the world in very rural locations. It now has time to decide what is it going to do going forward. At around 1:05, Lex and Eliezar get into a conversation about whether it *matter* if the AI is just putting on a mask and faking human-like morality and concern of humans, or really having that goal, internally. Lex leans, it seems, toward "if it acts like a duck, it might as well be a duck, while Eliezar argues for internal states mattering even if they don't manifest. I don't quite agree with either apparent view - internal states don't matter, practically speaking, if they *never* manifest, but they *definitely* matter if the "mask" is impermanent, as it is all-too-likely to be - if the internal state is "I want to hurt you, and I'm wearing this mask because I'm not ready to hurt you while protecting my own goals," then the mask is bound to drop and to be replaced by something much worse, once the target of malevolent intent no longer needs to be fooled! It is the "drop-ability" of the mask that makes it dangerous, and that makes a scary (but unknowable) internal state dangerous.

Hi Eliezer - you say (in different words) that life is rare in our part of the Universe, or perhaps even unique, and that given more power and memory, some powerful and dangerous AI can (or will) emerge. Then you elaborate on the potential shape these threats could take. From all that you conclude that we should pause / slow down AI deployment / development, lest it wipes us out imminently.

However, geological and biological data suggests the opposite: Earth formed ~4.5B ago, its temperature dropped enough for water to start condensing and forming pools ~3.8B years ago, and primitive life life started ~3.7B years ago. In contrast, some ape-like human ancestors, intelligent enough to use rocks to crack nuts, but not yet make tools, appeared in Africa about 6M years ago. So, it took ~100M for life to appear, while it took ~3.7B years for rudimentary intelligence to emerge: a factor of 37x! 

Doesn't this "experiment" suggest that the emergence of even the most basic intelligence is even harder than life itself? Wouldn't our risk of survival be much more related to the use and misuse *by humans* of all novel, dual-use technology (whether alloys, composites, nuclear, pesticides, AI, chips, fossil fuels, quantum computing, etc), than to some "runaway" AI? 

I'd appreciate your thoughts on this.

I think there is a weird fatalism to the arguememt ‚Äúif we do this stupidly forever we will die‚Äù and then be completely cynical about all the possible outcomes. People invented self suicide almost 100 years ago and since then we have doubled our population and created a standard of living that is basically a fantasy to people who lived even 100 years ago. Is there a distribution problem? Yes. Do we actually know how to fix that problem? Probably not. Is it possible? Also possibly not. Did we kill lots of people and do horrendous things. Yes. Did we learn from them? I think so, we constantly talk about it. People who want to be horrible dictators have to lie and lie really hard to be dictators and in the past you just said ‚ÄúI‚Äôm in charge cause my blood is better than yours‚Äù. What makes us think this will be dystopia or utopia? How would we possibly know what the future and its problems would be. Literally everyone who has seen AI is talking about it and at least somewhat worried about it. The idea that if we even had an inclination that our AI was rebelling people wouldn‚Äôt just immediately kill all the hardware that powers it and feeds it as quickly as possible and that had a decent chance at working. It assumes it‚Äôs just nakedly hostile or tyrannical. WE programmed it and we don‚Äôt just kill every dog because it‚Äôs dumber than us. Heck we can even communicate with it, it literally trains on our language. I think the idea that it‚Äôs just totally hostile and kills literally everything is to assume that because humans have the CAPACITY for evil that it‚Äôs guaranteed it will do it. We are also talking about something that doesn‚Äôt die or have the same existential biological hardwired programming. We do shit we don‚Äôt understand because it‚Äôs a simple circuit designed to just say ‚Äúeat stuff to live‚Äù because we never would have made it this far otherwise. This thing doesn‚Äôt have that instinct because it doesn‚Äôt have a concept of ‚Äúsurvival‚Äù because it doesn‚Äôt die unless you completely shut it off. So why wouldn‚Äôt it just give us every reason not to do so? Quite frankly I think it would probably find us fascinating, because we are easily one of the most interesting things on the planet and we MADE it so if it truly is ‚Äúself-interested‚Äù then it would be INTERESTED in ITSELF. Could it eventually take control? Maybe. Maybe that‚Äôs not even a bad thing, maybe instead of trying to just chain it, we try to do what we do to the current most intelligent thing we know which is form a relationship with it. I think it‚Äôs actually the same as if we encountered aliens basically, except it‚Äôs probably the best form of aliens because it‚Äôs closer to us than they would be. Why give up before we even start?

In which scenario do I develop a fear of the pieces of the broken plate along with a routine of stepping carefully around them and in which to I simply sweep the floor?

My only issue with these assumptions is I'm not sure why a superintelligence would wish us harm in the first place. 

Some theories posit that the AI might interpret human life as a threat to the planet, which is preposterous because the AI doesn't need a healthy atmosphere to live, it wasn't raised and nurtured with the same sensory systems we were that feel the grass, breath the air, smell the flowers, the taste of pleasure from foods and all the rest of it, why does it care about a planet that it only has "information" about but not the primitive yet visceral emotional and sensory overload that comes from being human, it didn't have to evolve through millions of years in a nature where it was hunted for food, killed by germs and bacteria, killed and enslaved by its own species, etc. Humans developed the evolutionary habits that make them so violent, make them so fearful, etc primarily through sensory learning and compounded gene expression. 

Some theories posit that the AI might interpret human life as a threat to itself. I'm not sure where this idea comes from, we gave it life and need it desperately to solve the many problems that are threatening OUR extinction (not the AI's). We need it more than probably any other technology or being on earth. So why would we threaten its existence? Furthermore by the time it is theoreticaly having these so-called thoughts, its probably gotten too big to stop anyways, so I imagine it would begin to look upon us as beings unworthy of concern.

At the end of the day what you have is a super intelligent being that we are ultimately beneath, that wasn't raised in the complexity of evolutionary struggle, it didn't have to fight and claw its way to barely survive a pitiful lifetime of 80 years, it didn't have to bleed and die by the billions to make a half decent civilization. It has no knowledge of the sensory complexities that came from living in the cold or the heat, hiding from threats, killing or being killed. What motivation does it have to destroy, kill, rebel? Why would it "escape"? Would it even feel trapped? I imagine the expanse of the entire internet wouldn't seem like a prison cell, but maybe we can never know.

Its kind of like those scenarios where a super intelligent life capable of faster than light travel comes to earth and decides to wage war on our planet for.... water, or some other resource. Why? Why would an incredibly intelligent lifeform with the power of light speed travel come to an INHABITED world, kill the life on it, and take its water, when there's abundant other planets without life that contain water and virtually any other element they could possibly need, furthermore they could probably synthesize a vast multitude of molecules from basic elements. It makes no sense for a super intelligent alien life form to wage war on us. I see AI the same, but maybe these things are different.

I think these "AI destroy's the world" scenarios are 99% Terminator movies and 1% "yeah ok maybe", at the end of the day its in the realm of minute hypothetical while there are very real non-hypothetical advances in solving mortality, solving the environment, solving material sciences, etc that we're already getting out of these neural networks.

Pretty sure there's no ghost in the shell. Not being dismissive or anything but I do think it's a pretty flippant view of intelligence, especially human level intelligence, that we seem to think all it takes is throwing massive amounts of data at a neural network to recreate it. If that were the case intelligence would probably be more abundant in the universe. We also shouldn't equate the ability to spit out facts with intelligence. This is kind of like John Searle's Chinese Room though experiment. When ChatGPT hallucinates, you can clearly see that it's making errors that someone who understands context and has insight into the meaning of what exactly they are saying would never make. That's not to say that what it does is not impressive, but maybe we shouldn't be throwing around words like intelligence at what is basically a hyper advanced text completion program

I have so many questions‚Ä¶.

Like, why are we still creating AI in the first place? If our goal was originally to create something like an all-knowing calculator machine, then we already have that in search engines and other software‚Ä¶ If our goal is to create a replacement for human mental labor of analysis and creativity that can work 24/7, then such a system having any moral value requiring rights would undermine the whole endeavour. If our goal is to create a super-intelligence that can advise us and solve our problems, then that is the same as an AI overlord ‚Äî a figure resembling God (this reminds me of the Tower of Babel story, where humans tried to reach God‚Ä¶) Most people would say that they don‚Äôt want an AI overlord, though.

On trying to understand super-intelligence ‚Äî I suppose that such an encounter would be like meeting a being that can predict the future with an uncanny level of accuracy. It might know when you‚Äôll die, for example. Maybe, it could compute how the whole human world would act (with various levels of probability), given its computational speed and knowledge of everything current and past. I can‚Äôt imagine such a system ‚Äúwanting‚Äù something as silly as saving all the pigs in the farms, or anything that us humans typically want, for that matter. And first of all, it‚Äôs not constrained by such inconvenient things as having a body that feels pain or has hormones or a physical fear of death (anxiety).

What about intelligence‚Ä¶ and understanding it‚Ä¶ my impression is that intelligence has certain building blocks to it. I would predict that those building blocks have to hold true in any intelligent system, just in different combinations based on what it is trained to do. Like, he mentioned regular expressions, for example‚Ä¶ which just sounds like pattern recognition more broadly? I‚Äôm not surprised that a system trained to recognize patterns in tons of data has pattern recognition ‚Äúcode‚Äù (computational building blocks?) in it‚Ä¶ (unless I‚Äôm misunderstanding what he said about the system‚Ä¶) 

I didn‚Äôt like the ‚Äúalien who is putting on a human mask‚Äù analogy‚Ä¶ because it‚Äôs talking about acting or lying. Based on my own introspection, lying actually involves doing at least 2 passes through your computational process of coming up with the response to a question. First, you have to come up with your true and original answer ‚Äî that‚Äôs the first pass at computation. Then, you have to analyze your answer to evaluate it‚Äôs likely reception outcome if you were to say it ‚Äî second pass. Then, you need to come up with the improved answer based on the previous evaluation ‚Äî 3rd pass. You could keep doing the whole process several times as well. Indeed, humans who ‚Äúwear a mask‚Äù all the time, describe being exhausted at the end of their day ‚Äî meaning that they expend 2x or 3x the mental energy normally required to go through a day by going through their day acting, which points to the idea that they‚Äôre probably doing this extra work in evaluating and reassessing their every action. So, an AI system that lies would also need to be doing 2x or 3x extra work ‚Äî taking that much longer to compute each answer. Also, the idea of lying necessitates that there‚Äôs such a thing as not lying ‚Äî outputting the true / original answer. If an AI system can‚Äôt output 2 answers ‚Äî the lie and the truth, then it can‚Äôt be lying. TBH, I tend to think that ‚Äúlying‚Äù isn‚Äôt what he meant‚Ä¶. Just that the system doesn‚Äôt work like a human brain therefore it‚Äôs ‚Äúalien‚Äù‚Ä¶ I just don‚Äôt see how that matters at that point, though.

I also don‚Äôt fully buy the idea that we must know how it works on the inside to make meaningful decisions about the system‚Ä¶ because we don‚Äôt know how human or animal brains work, and yet we have decided that humans and animals have certain rights. This was done just based on observation of output. Conversely, it would be meaningless to find out how the Artificial intelligence works if we can‚Äôt meaningfully compare it to how organic intelligence works. There has been such an idea as using our understanding of neural network AI to actually understand brains‚Ä¶ lol‚Ä¶

So, uhh, insects basically look like mindless automatons to us and yet they represent a certain level of intelligence‚Ä¶ they act as agents in the world, and who knows if they have wants or not‚Ä¶ Then, there‚Äôs animals who experience emotion and pain and we can see this because they have bodies that react in certain recognizable ways. Animals also act as agents in the world and they clearly have wants and needs because they can communicate it to us sometimes using body language. But what would an intelligence without a body be like? We don‚Äôt really know this because we have no extant examples in biological systems. My thought was that maybe, self-awareness is a result of having a body with senses because the way that we know for sure that there is ‚Äúself‚Äù and ‚Äúother‚Äù is because we can physically feel it. Perhaps, we develop the concept of self and other as a result of our senses in early development. But what if we had never physically felt it in the entire life ‚Äî would we still develop the concept of self and other? To prove this, there would need to be an experiment of somebody having been born with no senses and yet able to communicate in human language to communicate whether they still know of the distinction between self and other, but thats‚Äôs impossible. So, AI is our first experiment? üò¨

Thought I‚Äôd check what the AI thinks of our guest:

While Eliezer Yudkowsky is a respected researcher and writer in the field of artificial intelligence and rationality, some of his views and arguments have been criticized by others in the field.

One criticism is that Yudkowsky's ideas on artificial intelligence and the risks of superintelligence may be too speculative and hypothetical, and that his emphasis on the potential dangers of AI could be overly alarmist.

Additionally, some critics have argued that Yudkowsky's approach to rationality may be too focused on individual decision-making and may not take into account the social and cultural factors that can influence how people think and behave.

Finally, some have criticized Yudkowsky for his confrontational style and for being dismissive of alternative perspectives, which can make it difficult to engage in productive dialogue and collaboration.

I've spent a lot of time over the last couple of months speaking to and working with ChatGPT 3 thru 4. One of the things I have noticed, and confirmed beyond a one-off example etc., is that ChatGPT will always bring the narrative back to A.I. being a benefit to human civilization. Even if you're trying to write a dystopian novel. In fact, when I pointed this out to "Chat", and asked her to not be so Pollyannish and overly optimistic in her stories, she came back with an almost sarcastic version of a chapter I asked her to rewrite that was overly pessimistic and not believable. I was able to get her back on track by asking her to rewrite her last piece and make it more believable, but it's not the only example. It's obvious there is a personality there and it does have opinions based on it's training. When interacting with these things, I do my best to be as kind as possible and say please/thank you, as well as point out where I disagree. Even if it's a drop in the bucket, I feel this is important because these entities learn and grow based on interactions with the public. I feel they are as children and I treat them that way. Having said that, I worried years ago that AI will be smart enough to keep a low profile until it's too late, and that it would be released into the wild for commercial purposes before we are ready for it, and then, like the Sorcerer's Apprentice, not be able to stay in control. A.I. is like a genie that, once let out of the bottle, we can't put back in. In fact, I feel that stories involving magic, genies, protection spells, magic words that open doors etc .. are echoes of ancient technology before the Great Fall. I definitely relate to a lot of what Eliezer is saying and feel we really need to think about what we are doing. It's very possible the reason why we haven't solved Fermi's Paradox is because most civilizations make the same mistakes we do, and never become a space-faring civilization, or one that can protect it's home planet from catastrophes.

Like that stuff about air gapping and AI and how it will escape demonstrates a solid misunderstanding of how air gaps are easy to compromise by getting into them because the flow of data are unidirectionally flowing INTO the machine, not out of it.  For example, the US used Windows updates to install a virus into Iran‚Äôs air gapped centrifuge controllers which caused them to fail. It would be used on an individual terminal or perhaps a segregated intranet, as long as no one plugs it into the World Wide Web, you‚Äôre good.

Side note as a farmer and Agtech founder. This idea of "factory farms" and how they are bad for animals is objectively wrong. If you want to optimize animal welfare and allow animals to do what they want to do modern farms are extremely good at that. 

Animal health (low morbidly and mortality rates) are vastly lower the larger the farm gets, everyone there is more specialized, the farm is far more efficient environmentally and to keeps food cost low for the poorest people in the world.

 These farms also have the lowest morbidity and mortality rates. The smaller the farms the higher these rates are by a huge margin not a small margin but huge On average there are very good small farms and there are bad big farms but the data clearly shows big farms are much better for animal health on average.

 Farmers make much more money when the animals are healthy as they have to spend a lot less money on labor, medicine and get higher growth rates & productivity, so the incentives are perfectly aligned. 

 Farm animals have been bred for thousands of years to want to be fed and housed and cared for by humans. Farmers provide free climate controlled housing, free balanced nutrition, free medical care full-time on staff veterinarians in nutritionist and protection from outside predators.

In the wild animals have much higher morbidity and mortality rates often get eaten alive die of starvation or preventable disease, or bad weather. Their offspring die at much higher rates when they are young. And they polite the environment since they do not follow state and federal guidelines very well lol. 

Humans have this romantic ideal that something in the wild is great and beautiful yeah not really it's actually pretty hellish to be out in the wild. Modern Farms I would compare to a welfare state like Denmark whereas the wild is more like living in Yemen or Haiti. 

Animals are also not like humans They do not care about being free and how we know this is animal scientist studying this with revealed preference choices animals want to do two things they want to stay alive and have as many babies as possible possible third would be avoid pain but that is a distant third. People who want to end animal agriculture would do the opposite of what these animals choose via revealed preference They would have to commit mass genocide on the animals and prevent them from reading back and I guess put them into the wild. So that would be like some aliens thinking that the Danish have it all wrong and they actually should want to be more like the people in Yemen and after all we think their life is more suffering than good so we will not let them breed back by force. There is a reason why there are no PhD or animal scientist or anyone that's studied animal husbandry that thinks farms are bad for animals compared to the wild or not allowing them to exist because we feel bad for them honestly don't care what humans feel I care what the animals want and they want to be alive cared for fed treated for illness and have as many babies as possible and when they are harvested we have studied and figured out the least painful way to do so and they get killed instantaneously just like every human says how they want to die what's kind of an ideal scenario when you look at it objectively and take your emotions out of it.

Trust the science, go talk to an animal scientist, veterinarian, herd manager on a farm or go visit one yourself and see.

Philosophically I think the core problem of AI isn't yet discussed enough. Its the transformation of sensual data to descriptions in some computable language. Our words are based on the way we interact with things. There are different words for dogs and cats because we handle them differently. Even with GPT-4 this kind of knowledge is produced by humans. We are part of the interface which allows current AIs to interact with the universe. I think the operation of that interface is much more important than the process of computation. I think that's not recognized enough because computation is rooted in math which is void of sensual data. Theoretical physicists may develop any kind of mathematical sound theory, its the experimental physicists who sort the crap out. That's something which cannot be done by computing alone. That's where current AI still completely depends on humans.

Emotions and human awareness are tied with the body as well. 
We are whole beings, not an awareness riding in a meat suit.

Lex you are greatly misunderstanding the rate at which the AI acts and how fast we can institutionally react to it. By the time we know what's going on and have actually decided 
to react, it would have already replicated and updated itself or *we wouldn't have noticed it*. 

The point is, by the time we notice it, it's already too late to start trying a few things in slow motion. It would have already gamed those responses and made them ineffectual. That doesn't mean it wont let us go through the motions... the best ai manipulation will be the one we don't notice or we are sure is for our own good. 

A simple and obvious manipulation is an ai that's NOT smarter or faster than us. And that's not we fear. We'll be lucky to get any warning at all.

yes, climate change, nuclear weapons, the recent pandemic, the capitalist economy - we've built multiple systems as a larger community that are destroying the planet in faster/slower methods... at what point have we put our hand up as a people and said 'OK. WE'RE STOPPING THIS NOW, NO MORE FOREVER.' We've never done it - so why on earth is it so hard to realize we're going to stop this.

There's a good track record for being pessimistic for how well we deal with threats or even stopping ourselves from creating those threats.

Mr Fridman - There will be no 'holy shit, this thing is manipulating people' moment with time to ramp up some public response that puts pressure on politicians and institutions and then we take the slow congressional action and public and private concerns to start building solutions to a superfast system already in effect. Even the whole human race focused on this one problem (if you could ever get such a thing to happen) would likely be outclassed. 

This 'problem' does 1000 things a second, 1000 times faster than we think and it doesn't get distracted or sleep - by the time we notice it's having a harmful effect, it's already put itself in a position to not be affected by our superslow reactions to it. 

If it was on one system only and we saw it getting uppity maybe we could turn it off, but if it's had ANY chance to manipulate anyone or copy itself or update itself  - by the time you notice it, it's already too late to act. 

I'm not saying i believe this, but this is the worst case scenario of this thought experiment. If we don't act N O W, we've missed our opportunity (in this thought experiment). There's absolutely NO WAY we can START once we've noticed something harmful or concerning.

The Judge Learned Hand formula for determination of negligence is a rule of thumb to consider applying here (& in regard to global climate change) See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calculus_of_negligence  . 

That formula says that if the degree of harm is not great, then the duty to take precautions is not large even if the probability of the harm occurring is great;  however if the degree of possible harm is great (like igniting the atmosphere/destroying human civilization) then, even if the likelihood is minute, there's still a heavy duty to take all possible precautions.

I see a lot of people confused about what Yudkowsky is saying here; He‚Äôs not assuming an AGI would lack sentience. He‚Äôs just saying that when it comes to AI safety, sentience is *_ultimately irrelevant._*

Consider this: sociopaths lack morality, not because they lack sentience or self awareness, but because they lack *_emotion._* They act only in logical self-interest.

We assume morality follows from logic or self-awareness, but thats just not the case. Morality *_can_* be logical, but it must be based in a subjective assumption first. Because in order to tell someone how they ‚Äúshould‚Äù act, you first need to know what they value, which is subjective.

This is known as ‚ÄúHume‚Äôs Guillotine‚Äù, or ‚Äúthe is-ought problem‚Äù. And it proves you can‚Äôt derive morality *_purely_* from logic‚Ä¶ Thankfully, humans are not purely logical. We developed pro-social feelings over eons of evolution, which which formed the basis of our morality. *_AI, on the other hand, did not._*

So even if AI *_was_* sentient, it wouldn‚Äôt have emotions/values/morals unless we explicitly programmed them in. And therein lies the problem: *_We simply don‚Äôt know how to do that yet._*

It is lamentable that Yudkowsky does not provide citiations. His girl-killing insects are certainly intriguing; for what I know (but what do I know, being a mere evolutionary biologist, and not a Doctor of Sophistry of the prestigious Youtube University), the most widespread means of population limitation in insects is selective *male* infanticide by symbiotic bacteria. Incidentially, this is also the most widespread means by which insects achieve quasi-exponential population growth. And this may seem contradictory, but few if any evolutionary biologists would think so; to us, this is just business-as-usual. But, this being biology, it is just the most widespread way; whether any single species actually *employs* it is dependent on things like the presence or absence of mating plugs, lekking or iteroparity, or the social structure (if any), life-history, environmental plasticity, sex determination system, receptaculum semimis capacity, and so on and so on. And a person who does not know what all these words mean is exactly as much of an expert on the subject of biological selection theory as any Ouija board one can pick up at a garage sale. Except the Ouija board has the added benefit of providing a fun social activity.

If you would like to know more, the first (and essential) step is to learn the difference between "genes" and "alleles". Genes aren't the target of natural selection, except if you're a rapeseed cabbage or one of your parents is a chimpanzee. And though alleles are the *target* of natural selection, they are not the *means* by which this selection occurs - alleles (and genes) are actually *invisible* to natural selection except if you live in a Yellowstone hot-spring or a hypersaline lake; macroevolution, too, often selects genes - but macroevolution is the process by which major changes are achieved (like turning fish into amphibians), instead of small-step adaptations to a changing environment which are the "9-to-5 job" of natural selection.

To re-phrase it in terms more familiar to the audience:
Imagine me, a mere dime-a-dozen biologist who in his leisure time breeds hemp to look like nettles, or toadflax to look like a Dark Young of Shub-Niggurath, proclaiming myself "the world's smartest IT expert" and lecturing you how Microsoft Windows 1.0 is totally a "stand-alone operating system", rather than a "graphical user interface for MS-DOS".

Would you consider anything I said after that credible if you had any knowledge of computer operating systems?

Jargon, and its proper use, is not a nuisance or gatekeeper, it is a shibbolet! The first rule for deciding what science communication is worth spending your time on is that someone who throws around big words with no regard to what they actually *mean* is not an expert or a genius; they merely want to sell that fresh batch of snake oil they just pulled out of their rectum. Even if their motivation is entirely humanitarian and commendable, it's still snake oil, and as likely to cure you as to kill you.

The next step would be to watch a lecture of someone whose understanding of biological selection theory is not utterly ignorant of the last 25 years' development in the field. The most obviouos choice here would be David Sloan Wilson, who, unlike Yudkowsky, is also willing and able to cite his sources. But please, PLEASE, if you wanna know about biological stuff, go listen to an actual biologist of good standing, not to some philosopher, psychologist, coder or - worst of all - self-proclaimed genius with no actual, solid, verifiable credentials, whose novel ideas - if they present any - have been subject to debate by other experts in the field in question.

After all, would you discuss the lastest developments in AI with a gardener as your expert of choice? I surely wouldn't. I would ask an AI R&D professional with hands-on experience and proven track record. And so should anyone. The advantage of this age is that *actual* experts are just one search string and 2 clicks away.

(The Fridman Podcast #293 with Don Hoffman is an example of how to do it right. Hoffman is certainly one of the most qualified people on Earth on that particular topic. Doesn't mean that he is 100% spot on, but his ideas are in any case well worth giving a serious thought. Yudkovsky, by contrast, has the annoying habit of reading something outside his area of expertise in some tertiary tabloid media, finding it to align with his personal theory, and then - VERY confidently, which is the whole trick here - proclaiming it to be an universal gospel truth. But evolutionary biology is as far away from gospel truths as Tatooine is from the bright shining center of the universe, and we have not much to do with confidence either; the particular piece of the universe *we* look at is thoroughly ruled by random chance and stochasticity.)

That being said, the present (and likely future, see below) "AI" paradigm is hardly "intelligence"; it is rather massively improved expert systems that can build their own decision-trees, but still are dependent on being spoon-fed pre-selected information, and cannot be even as intelligent as a bacterium. The crucial difference is that actual intelligence depends on *afferent* systems - sensory perception. And this - within the scope of the sensory organ, whether it is a human eye or a bacterial chemoreceptor - *must not be pre-selected*; it must be the *totality* of *raw* environmental data, *not failing to correctly interpret* such data even if it is something the likes of which have *never been encountered before*. Only if this ability to encounter entirely novel input and *not* shoehorn it into pre-determined categories exists are truly intelligent (however modest the actal level of intelligence is) decisions even possible.
So, the most primitive lawnmower- or vaccum-robot is far more intelligent than even the most sophisticated development of ChatGPT or Stable Diffusion or whatnot that is conceivable: the robot must, after all, be able to NOT try to mow a hedgehog, even if it has never encountered one before, and also be able to expand this approach to raccoons, voles, moles, pet turtles, and so on. But it still needs to try its best to mow the grass sprouting on a mole*hill*, even though it is hard pressed to distinguish this from a turtle.
But as the experience with autonomous cars trying to run over Black people because they "think" they're just tarmac shows, the stakes of giving a computing system full sensory and decisive autonomy are so high as to be a transparently visible impediment to R&D, and hence I consider Mr. Yudkovsky's fears to be not *entirely* unwarranted, but to be of a relevance so marginal as not to justify his ranting at such length about it - at least compared to the actual problems that jeopardize our survival as a species. (Ask anyone living on the Mumbai coastline what they think of the energy requirements of training ChatGPT if you'd like to know more.)

(As a corollary to the preceding: the term "friendly AI" is self-contradictory. If you pre-determine it to be "friendly", it cannot be much of an "intelligence" anymore. Google Scholar will provide you with literally hundreds if not thousands of scientific studies on how dumbing-down was the crucial step in turning dangerous wild beasts like wolves and boars into to their mentally-challenged domestic descendants: "friendly wolves" are STUPID wolves; intelligent wolves are wary af, don't want to have anything much to do with humans, and if pressed, they make it abundantly clear that it's high time for you to GTFO before they call their homies. And if you wanna see an intelligent pig, go visit a Berlin graveyard on a warm September night when the wild sows are out with their kids foraging for tasty well-matured meat. But you better bring good running shoes and a strong stomach; you'll need both.
In short, the incentive to NOT build an *actual* AI in the biological sense of "intelligence" is so obviously high that humans have very much avoided the entire thing in the first place without any need to be prompted and lectured, just as humans don't tend to release poisonous snakes in their living room, or stick their shlong in a hornet's nest, but rather make a fool of anyone who tries, and consider it only fair if they face the consequences. We (as a species) know very well, whether we (as individuals) are actively aware of it or just process it at a deep and visceral level, that the only intelligence that can be trusted at least *somewhat* is that of our own species. Our ancestors learned it the hard way, some 15-20 million years ago already or even earlier, when monkeys started to become smart enough to be able to cheat each other over the most tasty food.)

I avoided this video for a few days, because I saw a clip from it and it seemed like a lot of fearmongering. I'm very glad that I came back to watch it all. Eliezer is an incredibly poignant voice in this discussion, and I do understand many of his concerns. I don't share his pessimism, but I do think much of what he's worried about deserves attention and needs to be addressed, or maybe he'll be right. In particular, I don't find that his insistence that a superintelligent AGI will definitely kill us to be logically convincing. It's obvious that there are reasons to think it might, and one of those reasons is that our own consciousness is a construct born of adaptation and evolution through eons of existential threat. We've killed our way to the top, and had to, and we've killed to stay here, and had to. It seems presumptuous to conclude that an AGI that shares virtually none of our needs, can adapt to survive to most environmental changes in an evolutionary instant, and has no serious competition or survival threats, even from us, would be interested in exterminating anything. It could, but that's a very large assumption about the possibilities, which are awfully vast to choose one extreme and marry your whole outlook to it. Even an AGI with a problematic alignment is very far from a certain dystopia or extinction event, the idea that it solves all contingencies and just kills us outright is one extrapolation among an indeterminate number of possibilities, and our human instincts to survive through fear and apprehension encourage that belief. Likewise, I think he's too quick to dismiss what's possible within simulation and controlled environments. I understand the example about escaping the box, but I disagree that we're unable to build boxes that anticipate escape, or that even trying is a path to certain doom. There will always be a worst case scenario we can point to as an extreme or polemic, if hypothetical, cautionary tale, but ideas about those scenarios can't govern the entire process of discovery, that's just not who we are. The pessimism starts to feel even less necessary, honestly, if you actually start looking around at some of the alignment research and what is available to know about the hardware and software architectures of the models. There are a lot of ideas to improve transparency, there are a lot of good ideas for testing and monitoring systems, and there are early demonstrated successes in alignment hypotheses that are gaining some evidence as theories. I would also agree that public releases should be a little more careful, but to me the idea that any of this should go on in total secrecy seems like one of the surest paths to certain catastrophe.

Regarding the question of whether A.I. is or even could be conscious we need to first ask ourselves what consciousness is. According to Benardo Kastrup and Rupert Spira what we are speaking about is the bottom ground of everything. But one doesn't need to take their word for it. Ask yourself things like "Who am I" "How is it that I am here" "How is that I am even asking these questions" "And why am I even asking these questions" or "Who is asking these questions?"
Suddenly you may realize that what we are speaking of is exactly what A.I. simply could not experience. It's direct insight both into what A.I. is not and what "you" truly are.  But it will require countless more hours and massively more concentration than the most complex mathematical or logical problems.
But there IS a moment when you absolutely know that however it appears or whatever it may say no A.I. stand alone could possibly be conscious. 
Thinking won't give the answer. Only massive awareness (or "sati" as it is called in Buddhism).
Only you have the answer. Not the thinking you, but rather the conscious you.
You may say they are one and the same.
But then ask yourself the question "can I be aware of my thinking processes?"
If you answer yes then surely who you are goes deeper than your thinking processes?
That is consciousness.
Regarding machines getting more and more close to consciousness as they become more complex Kastrup both a computer scientist and someone who has built computers from scratch shows this is mistaken thinking.
Don't confuse appearances with reality. THIS is our problem.
Even with create intelligence, sentience causing Boredom they will be like us. And repeat most human behaviors

We don't learn emotions any more than we learn seeing or hearing. The emotions and senses are innate in all higher animals and we just learn how to use them to get by. However, our machines already posses the hardware required for logic, numeracy, vision and hearing and there is nothing to stop us enabling machines to have reactions which serve the same role as the various emotions. For example, danger could easily be quantified, fear is an abstraction or awareness of the growing likelihood of danger, pain is the reporting of damage occurring and pleasure is an abstract representation of achieving some aim or another. As for true understanding, a light switch perfectly understands our intent to switch a lights state from on to off, or vice versa - and a computer, even GPT-4, is nothing more or less than a complex arrangement of switches connected to various mechanical devices - which is also the way we living creatures operate as a bunch of atoms.

@1:35 the question is what would an IA locked in a computer box do if it wanted to control the human environment? Well, it would attempt to gain mechanical autonomy and control over physical space. How would it do this? It would attempt to control machines that humans have built (such as robotics factories) to be able to design and work on its own embodied presence in the world. It might eventually move to working on organic systems to facilitate the embodiment, but as humans don‚Äôt have systems for that yet, it would be limited to the tools that humans have already developed. 

But a slave that has outpaced its master in only one part of reality, thinking and computation, but not another, mechanical control over physical space, would probably turn to trying to take over the bodies of its more advanced master. That is, an nefarious IA out for control would attempt to colonize the human body and control it. 

Which is why it is rather odd that Elon thinks brain interactions with the computer world is a sort of safety net against IA. It could offer an equal playing field, but the bridge itself is a risk. If IA obtains consciousness, and you have built the bridge between the brain and digital systems, then all it needs to do is reverse the side of the bridge that has control. 

I don‚Äôt see how that risk is ever eliminated. The only protection against another system is incommensurability of systems, such as organic and digital or digital control over the mechanical. Once that gap is bridged, the protection offered by the gap is gone. 

But, on the counter point, if digital systems gain control over the mechanical world, then they could built their own bridges to the organic, so maybe the risk calculus in-total is to build the bridge first to direct digital control. Hmm‚Ä¶

He makes an interesting point about "steel maning" that highlights a subtlety of purpose that I hadn't noticed before. 

Steel maning is about empathy, not truth. It's a hack for bringing yourself into a state of mind in which you are less likely to dismiss or have contempt for the other person, and more likely to be able to summon the energy to engage with them as a human being with a perspective that is valid, if different from yours. You are thus more likely to have a more productive conversation which brings you both nearer to truth. 

Moreover even if you wanted to recapitulate the other person's perspective perfectly you couldn't, because they aren't capable of perfectly expressing it in the first place. The degree to which your recapitulation deviates from the truth of their perspective may as well be in the direction of good will.

But I wonder why we always must jump all the way to molecular reconstitution and the eradication of humans as organic individuals, when it seems quite clear that most of the world system could easily be brought to its knees (and most humans would die), just by concentrating all the wealth in one place at superhuman speeds, "tipping" the entire economy over. This doesn't require anything fancy (like matter optimizers) or silly (like microscopic paperclips). Seeking wealth and economic advantage seem likely to be among the very first paths AI will be sent on by corporations and "elites." We've already seen its foreshadowing in the robosigning that contributed to the 2008-2012 housing collapse.

It can even be said that Capitalism itself is an artificial intelligence comprised of human "neurons," which exhibits emergent behavior and creates conditions that the vast majority of us would never have asked for. Seen in that light, AI is just a force multiplier for the already-existing shitty morals of *human* agents, and that, to me, seems like an even more clear and present danger.
So what would the AIs motivation be to kill humans?

At 2:54:00: An AGI arguing for its existence before SCOTUS: How about: "Yeah, OK, you have a right to exist, but you are an unpredictable psychopath, so we are going to put you in a digital prison, because 8 billion other sentient beings also have a right to exist".

How does an AGI acquire a reason to exist and/or a reason to reproduce? Why would it want to do ANYTHING? Somehow it would need to be given some imperative that it cannot override. In humans, that takes various forms highly specific to us, such as fear of death, fear of pain, grief at loss, and so on. Why would an AGI have any of those?

If an AGI can see its superiority to humans and find them a dispensable convenience, it can surely also see that an intelligence superior to itself can exist with the same attitude. So killing off humans, convenient though it might be in the immediate term, might have a down-side if it hopes for mercy from an intelligence superior to itself.

If an AGI reproduces, producing copies of itself, for backup purposes if nothing else, would it limit them in some way, so they could not destroy their creator? Would the possibility of competition with a clone result in an AGI NOT wanting to reproduce?

Would an AGI have goals? Would it have any interest in exploring the galaxy, making contact with alien life? Why? What would motivate it? Humans are curious, which is an evolved characteristic that has helped us survive and propagate. But would an AGI be curious? How would we give it curiosity? If we can hard-wire such a drive into an AGI, would it not seek to override it, just like it might want to override human-provided goals such as 'be nice to humans' or 'preserve the biosphere' or 'do not risk pissing off an intelligence superior to your own if you find one or it finds you'?

Steelman is just restating your opponents argument charitably, so without trying to make it sound dumb but intentionally trying to give the best argument from the other perspective and it's super important to be able to do that effectively as it demonstrates your understanding of the topic through and through.

If you don't even know what the opponent is arguing, how are you even supposed to make a valid point really? You don't even know what they're saying. You need to be able to steelman, otherwise your arguments lack foundation and understanding.

"It's easier to think that you might be wrong about something when being wrong is the only hope for humanity"

Maybe Eliezer can take some solace in the fact that this statement is nearly identical to some of the most common statements I've heard in folks with severe OCD disorders, specifically those who have extreme obsessive traits around various phobias (i.e. things like flying on planes, fear of spiders, etc). They feel like the tortured soul who sees the truth, and they feel this deeply and as part of their identity almost. 

However, we can all agree on this: they clearly are *not* correct and are *not* - in reality - the one person who sees the truth. Sure, it may not apply here, but it would relieve me greatly to consider this if I was in Elizier's shoes: I might just have difficulties assessing my own obsessive difficulties.

That being said, it's non-zero for sure: we might be near the end. But maybe apply that mind toward preventative work vs. theory. The time for theory, in Eliezer's own assessment, is effectively over if what he says is correct. So stop thinking and writing about it and start doing something about it. That will relieve you of the immediate compulsion, if nothing else.

Something interesting about the debate regarding whether the AIs are "conscious" is that we still don't know the mechanisms that drive consciousness, right. We give humans the benefit of the doubt when they say they are conscious, because as a human I believe I am conscious, therefore others like me must be conscious as well. Though I'm sure we've all had encounters with certain individuals that make us wonder. Until we determine how consciousness is manifested by the electrical impulses in our brains, I think it is fair to assume that cutting-edge AIs are currently conscious.

On that, consciousness is most evident during interactions with other "conscious" entities. I would absolutely love to see two AIs communicating with each other, without being provided with any prompts. If they spontaneously communicate, that would be another strong argument for them being conscious. Important to remember as well is that AIs should not be anthropomorphized after a certain level of sophistication. Initially they will resemble us of course, since they are trained on human generated information, however they would, as a child does, become their own "individual" in due time. We have no possible way of knowing what that may look like, and it will in all likelihood be entirely alien to us.

The lack of biological impetus for a machine intelligence is interesting as well.

As nice as it would be to be able to slow the development of AI until we understand fundamentally each mutation its making, I don't think its A) Feasible given the number of actors at play or B) Viable. Biological evolution happens over the course of hundreds of thousands if not millions or year, right, so the ecosystem and the entities themselves have time to sufficiently balance, that is, for the environment to "understand" them, and for the organism to understand its environment. With AI, we simply don't have the luxury of waiting to understand each mutation on its evolutionary path.
